Seeing violence rise in his hometown of Chicago and other cities led by Democrats turned him away from the party, he said.

A former Peace Corps volunteer who met his wife in Africa, Wagner said he understands the problem of racial inequity but believes that Democrats haven’t succeeded in fixing it. He praised Trump for signing a prison reform bill and said he would support the president going further on the issue.

As a Catholic, Wagner said he opposes abortion and believes in a traditional view of family, which he said Trump has a good record on.

Wagner said his family takes pandemic precautions seriously and he mourns the more than 230,000 dead, but he said with medical treatments improving, the country can’t afford more economic closures.

Trump’s strength has been impressive, Wagner said.

“He is as tough as nails. Just look at how he recovered from COVID himself, holding four rallies a day. He’s worked really hard,” Wagner said.

— Dianna M. Náñez and Rebekah L. Sanders

7:30 p.m.: 2 downtown Phoenix businesses boarded up in case of protests

Anticipating protests following Election Day results, at least two businesses in downtown Phoenix have taken precautions to protect their buildings.

Snooze A.M. Eatery near Central Avenue and McKinley Street was seen boarding up its windows on Tuesday afternoon. According to Chris Lee, a Fix It Services manager, Snooze called the handyman company to board up their downtown location due to "alleged riots."

The Wells Fargo location in downtown Phoenix also mounted wood boards over their exterior windows.

"We're just kind of closely monitoring things out of an abundance of caution and for the safety of employees and customers," said LiAna Enriquez, a Wells Fargo spokesperson in Phoenix. "We're aware of concerns of the possibility of post-election demonstrations."

The downtown location is the only one in Arizona that will board up its windows, Enriquez said, because it is close to the Capitol where numerous protests were held over the summer.

"As a precaution, we are boarding windows of a small number of branch locations in select cities. Any branches that have been boarded are operating normally, unless they were already temporarily closed due to COVID-19," Enriquez said in a statement.

Phoenix City Hall, which has also been a popular meeting spot for protesters this year, was not boarded up as of Tuesday evening, Phoenix Public Works Department spokesperson Yvette G. Roeder confirmed.

"However, the Public Works Department is prepared with materials, should the need arise," she said.

Several Arizona Department of Public Safety vehicles were seen in the parking lot of the Arizona House of Representatives on Tuesday evening, but spokesperson Bart Graves said troopers will be staffed at "normal levels" on Tuesday night.

The Phoenix Police Department Headquarters was surrounded by barricades as it has been since protests began in downtown Phoenix in May after the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

Maggie Cox, a Phoenix police spokesperson, said as of Tuesday evening, the department has "additional officers mobilized" and has been working with federal, state and local law enforcement partners to "ensure the safety of our community."

"While we have no information to indicate there will be criminal activity as a result of the election, we will continue to monitor activity related to demonstrations and responses will be determined by intelligence-driven information," Cox said. "We also remind community members, 'If you see something, say something.'"

— Jamie Landers and Emily Wilder

7 p.m.: Polls close in Arizona for anyone not already in line

Polls have officially closed across Arizona. However, any voter who was in line at 7 p.m. will be allowed to cast a ballot.

The first batch of results are expected around 8 p.m. Those results will consist of early ballots counted in the past several days and weeks.

Subsequent reports later in the evening will include ballots cast at polling places on Election Day.

Mail ballots dropped off on Election Day must go through the same signature matching and curing process as all the other mail ballots. These ballots may not appear in the results for a few days.

— Jessica Boehm and Andrew Oxford

6:45 p.m.: Hiral Tipirneni thanks voters before polls close

A little over an hour before polls closed, as a line of voters snaked through the campus of Paradise Valley Community College, congressional candidate Hiral Tipirneni stopped for one of the campaign’s final visits.

“Thank you for voting,” Tipirneni told voters as they streamed past, her voice a little muffled by a bright pink mask that said “VOTE” in sparkling silver.

A boy who looked old enough to vote told her he wasn’t. “Well, hopefully you’re with somebody who’s voting,” Tipirneni told him. “And in a couple years, you’ll be here to vote.”

Tipirneni, who is challenging Rep. David Schweikert in a close race, did not draw much attention. She stood outside the 75-foot electioneering boundary, hands folded at her waist, and thanked voters as they walked to the back of the line.

Few voters seemed to recognize the candidate. She turned to a group of campaign staffers behind her. “They’re like, who is this woman?” she said, referring to the people walking past. “And why is she all dressed up to come to the polls?”

A few minutes later, one of her staff walked off, and returned with a crisp white campaign sign. The staffer jammed the sign into the roots of a tree, and they headed to the next polling place.

— Alden Woods

6:35 p.m.: Trump voters energized in Tucson

An enthusiastic group of nearly 20 Republican voters gathered in the Tucson suburb of Casas Adobes on Tuesday afternoon to show their support for President Donald Trump with a few hours remaining before polls close in Arizona.

Many of these supporters said they chose to vote earlier in the day in person at the polls, taking cues from Trump, who has cast doubts on the safety of the vote-by-mail process despite no evidence of voter fraud.

“I’m not going to send my mail, the ballot for president of the United States. That is too severe and it’s too important. So I went to a polling place because I know that it’s more secure and it’s harder to be thrown out,” said Joseph Abeyta from Tucson.

The diverse group of supporters waved flags and signs, with cars honking in support or in opposition at the intersections of Oracle and Ina roads. The group gathered in front in the Safeway plaza where in 2011 a gunman shot and injured former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, whose husband, Mark Kelly is on the ballot as the Democratic Senate candidate.

This precinct is part of the Republican suburbs that ring the heavily Democratic city of Tucson, and had some of the highest vote totals in Pima County for Trump in 2016.

Melissa Shaw showed up to the rally with her 11-year-old daughter Trista after casting her ballot in person. She said her daughter was top of mind when she voted for Trump.

“I want a strong economy. I want her to go to college and work for something. I don’t want her to go to college and think, ‘Oh, all of my debt is gonna be paid off.' I want her to go to college and pay for it and earn it,” she said.

Pima County skews heavily Democrat. But in the last month of the campaign Trump and Vice President Mike Pence traveled to Tucson on multiple occasions to boost turnout among his supporters in hopes of offsetting his projected losses in southern Arizona.

— Rafael Carranza

6:30 p.m.: Youth excited to vote

Mohammed Mohammed, 23, of Tempe, voted for Joe Biden at Tempe Escalante Community Center.

He said he was driven to vote because he wanted to see racial justice and more education opportunities for young people.

“The most important thing that matters for me is a president that’s going to help the students, help with education. Kind of solve the systemic problems that we have in America today," Mohammed said.

Mohammed is one of hundreds of thousands of young people across the country committed to making their voices heard this election.

“All my friends are voting. The way that it was so crucial, especially for the year 2020, just made everyone vote," he said.

Mohammed said this election was the first time he took local elections seriously. He was eager to vote for Proposition 207, which would legalize recreational marijuana, because he believes Arizona will benefit from taxing marijuana.

— Dianna M. Náñez

6 p.m.: U.S. Postal Service misses order to sweep facilities for ballots

The U.S. Postal Service failed to meet a judge’s order on Tuesday for a sweep of its mail processing facilities in a dozen districts across the United States, including Arizona, to search for undelivered absentee ballots.

U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan ordered the sweep on Tuesday in a lawsuit filed by the NAACP and other groups after the Postal Service said about 300,000 ballots had not been scanned as delivered.

Other postal facilities singled out for inspection include some in central Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Detroit, Colorado/Wyoming, Atlanta, Houston, Alabama, northern New England, greater South Carolina, South Florida and Lakeland.

Sullivan, who is based in Washington, D.C., ordered the sweep for early Tuesday afternoon but the Postal Service said in a response it was “unable to accelerate" its ongoing daily review process to conduct the sweep "without significantly disrupting preexisting activities on the day of the election.”

The Postal Service said it is already conducting daily reviews of 220 facilities across the country handling election mail.

Rod Spurgeon, a spokesperson for the Postal Service in Arizona, said: “We do not currently have any issues impacting the timely delivery of ballots but will continue to monitor and be ready to adjust as needed.”

Sullivan wrote Tuesday that he would let the Postal Service’s ongoing process continue but added the agency “shall be prepared to discuss the apparent lack of compliance with the court's order” during a hearing on Wednesday.

— Andrew Oxford

5:30 p.m.: Disparate views in Glendale

People streamed steadily into the polling place at Glendale Community College in the mid-afternoon, but lines to vote in person were only a few minutes long, voters reported.

Fernando Cazares said equality for immigrants and LGBTQ people were key factors driving his vote for Joe Biden.

Although he respects Trump voters, he said he generally disagrees with Trump's policies.

“I want for everybody to be treated the same,” Cazares said.

Cazares, a 19-year-old caregiver, said it was his first time voting. He went to the Glendale Community College polling place on his day off with a friend to cheer him on who is an immigrant and could not vote.

“This election is going to be one for the history books,” Cazares said. “It feels good. People went through a lot just to be able to vote. Being able to vote in itself is a privilege.”

Wearing a camouflage Army hat and standing in the shade as the afternoon temperature hit 90 degrees, Calvin Hamilton said he was proud to vote for a second time for Trump.

“I wasn’t one of those silent voters,” Hamilton, 75, said. “I’m a Trumper.”

The military veteran said he likes Trump’s cuts to government and regulations.

“He kept his word. When’s the last time you could say that about a president?” Hamilton said.

The election is “paramount to the future,” Hamilton said. “We have more government than we need.”

Ryker Martin, 28, a Glendale resident aiming to become a teacher, said he had become disillusioned with the political process after voting for Hillary Clinton in 2016, so he cast a protest vote for president in 2020, writing in the "Star Trek" character Jean-Luc Picard.

“I think the left-right dichotomy is built out of fear,” Martin said. “It’s the same thing every time. … I’m tired of the same old, same old. I don’t see the point of voting for any party.”

Martin said he voted in favor of state propositions to legalize marijuana and to raise taxes on high-income earners to fund education, even though he worries some of the revenue raised for education will get wasted.

“I’ve been in situations when I was in high school where we couldn’t even pay for paper, but we had people with six-figure salaries overloading the administration,” he said. “But the schools do need money, and if it’s going to keep them afloat until we can fix something about it, it’s the best I can do.”

— Rebekah L. Sanders

5:15 p.m. Some vote centers busy while neighboring locations quiet

Some vote centers have seen long lines throughout the day, but locations just a few miles away from those sites have had no lines at all.

Voters can check wait times and lines at locations.maricopa.vote.

Surprise City Hall saw waits of 30 minutes or more throughout the afternoon. At about 5:20 p.m., the wait was about 51 minutes and there were more than 200 people in line. But just 2.4 miles away, R.H. Johnson Recreation Center in Sun City West reported no wait.

Mini Social, a location in downtown Scottsdale, also saw lines throughout the day. As of about 5:15 p.m., the wait was about 22 minutes and there were 69 people in line. Just 3 miles from there, Scottsdale Plaza Shopping Center saw a wait time of two minutes, with 10 people in line.

At the main voting location in Tolleson, Esther Angulo Community Center, the time to vote about 4:30 p.m. was about 38 minutes, with 122 people in line. About 2 miles away at Rio Vista School in Avondale, the wait was 2 minutes and there were 5 people in line.

— Jen Fifield

5 p.m.: Queen Creek voters allege voter harassment

Voters at a Queen Creek vote center reported being harassed shortly before 1 p.m. by people who honked horns at them, yelled at them and tried to take their photographs.

The incident, which took place at a higher education complex called Communiversity, was reported to the Arizona Secretary of State’s Office as well as to the Election Protection hotline run by the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.

“One of our field volunteers reported this issue and had the voter call into the hotline,” Election Protection spokesperson Ian Weiner said via email Tuesday afternoon.

“We received this complaint and were able to mobilize our coalition to address and ultimately resolve the issue. We sent a team of trained de-escalators (called “Election Defenders”) and raised it to the Secretary of State who also alerted the county to get the matter resolved," he said.

A spokeswoman for the Maricopa County Recorder’s office said she heard that individuals had yelled at voters, but that if it occurred outside the 75-foot limit surrounding polling places it was not illegal.

She added that anyone outside the 75-foot limit was also allowed to photograph anyone going into or out of a polling place.

She said the office also received reports that people were telling voters outside the polling place that they should use ballpoint pens on their ballots instead of the Sharpie pens provided in the voting booths.

Voters can use ballpoint pen in black or blue ink or a Sharpie, and vote centers use fine-tip Sharpies as they have the fastest drying ink. If ballpoint ink is not allowed to dry completely, it can smudge off onto the optical readers and spoil other ballots, according to the Maricopa County Recorder's Office.

A plainclothes Maricopa County Sheriff's deputy was sent to investigate and found that a woman was handing voters ballpoint pens with a flyer urging them to not use sharpies. The woman was told to stop and agreed to leave. The spokeswoman said new optical reading equipment was brought to the site to ensure ballots were read correctly.

— John D'Anna

4:45 p.m.: Growing line in west Phoenix

A line of about 40 people formed outside a west Phoenix vote center at Pendergast Early Learning Center in the afternoon.

Arizona State University criminal justice major Mario Torres, 21, was able to leave his shift at Amazon early to vote on Tuesday.

He said the company allowed employees three hours off to cast their ballots on Election Day.

Torres said he felt that the presidential race was the most consequential on the ballot because, "I don’t think who's in office right now is beneficial to our country.”

He said he's most concerned about racial injustice, environmental issues and the handling of the coronavirus pandemic. He said he's hopeful a new president will create change in those areas — even if it takes a while.

"Change probably takes a long time to happen, as we’ve seen. But having someone who is more humanistic will help our society," Torres said.

— José-Ignacio Castañeda

4:30 p.m.: Advocacy group alleges voter suppression

Members of the organization Mi Familia Vota reported that they have received complaints from Spanish-speaking voters across the country about threatening calls and false information intended to confuse and discourage them from voting.

"The reports we have received are about intimidation and false information that are causing confusion in our voters," said Eduardo Sáinz, state director of Mi Familia Vota in a press conference on Tuesday.

"Our message is clear: We have until today at 7 p.m. to participate in Arizona and we want our community to come out and vote to see the change we are waiting for," he said.

Sáinz did not present evidence, but said the reports come from reliable sources in the community.

He said that there is a helpline in Spanish that is 888-VE-Y-VOTA for people to call and report any false information or threats received regarding the elections.

Mi Familia Vota is a national civic engagement organization that advocates for social and economic issues that affect the Latino community, from immigration to worker rights.

4:15 p.m.: Active voters in central Phoenix

The first time she was eligible to vote, Pricilla Galaviz let the election pass by.

Not this time. The 22-year-old stopped by the Phoenix Union High School District Office vote center on her way to the gym to cast her first ballot, thinking the entire time of friends and family who didn’t have that option.

She wanted to represent her Latino community, like her friends with DACA status and her father, who’s a resident but not a citizen. Somebody needed to speak for them. Galaviz, who works as a medical assistant at a surgery center, believed her vote could help.

“It’s just more personal to me this year,” she said. “I’m voting for them. For the people who can’t.”

Asked to pick her most important vote, Galaviz said she couldn’t choose. She’d researched them all. The opportunity to vote at all felt “amazing,” she said.

“It’s just more personal to me this year,” she said.

Ruth Steen, a Phoenix elementary school teacher, spends her days around young people, and she wanted them to see that voting is important.

“If they could watch me go in and do it, maybe other people would walk in,” she said after casting a ballot in central Phoenix. “Maybe if I see more people actually going in, somebody will stop and go, ‘Oh, I should go vote.’”

Especially this year. Steen said she was particularly motivated to vote against President Trump — "I don’t like his character" — and for Proposition 207, which aims to legalize recreational marijuana in Arizona.

Steen said she’d done her research, and saw a benefit in the taxes that legalization would raise. “I heard the states that have done it have done very well, as far as getting money to go back to them,” she said.

— Alden Woods

3:45 p.m.: Mixed turnout in northern Arizona

The sun finally broke through thunderstorm clouds around 3 p.m. outside a voting location at Flagstaff Mall, where a handful of people lined up to vote.

It was a quiet affair, people meandering in and out of the poll with their young children, on their way to class at nearby Northern Arizona University or as they headed into the mall.

In the parking lot, a car emblazoned with pro-Biden bumper stickers and painted “Every Vote Matters!” sat only a few spaces from a truck flying a "Thin Blue Line" flag. Eventually they both pulled away, their drivers returning from inside each wearing “I Voted!” stickers.

Earlier in the day, about 40 people lined up in light rain outside a polling place at the Camp Verde Community Library. Thunder rumbled overhead, but most appeared to be in good spirits.

Alana Lewis, 18, was excited to participate in her first election.

“It’s time for a change,” she said, then shrugged. “It’s just a lot of chaos that happened this year and I’ve seen a lot of the president’s true side of who he is and how he runs things.”

Still in high school, she became politically aware with the Dakota Access Pipeline protests at Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota, which began in 2016. As a Native American, she said witnessing Trump’s response to the peaceful demonstrations there was eye-opening.

“It’s kind of discriminating. Why do people have to fight for human rights, you know?” she asked.

While not their first election, this was the first time Susan and Jerry Bennett came to vote in person. They came because they wanted to participate directly in this historic moment.

The two retirees came to vote for “democracy, capitalism, not socialism,” they said.

Several paces behind, Ron Bennett (unrelated) was less enthused about his choices. He asked with a laugh, “What are the lesser of two evils?”

Several people in line around him laughed and nodded in lighthearted disillusionment.

— Emily Wilder

3:15 p.m.: 18 ballots stolen but returned to voters

The Arizona Attorney General's Office announced that it believes 18 ballots were stolen out of individual mailboxes in Glendale late last week.

In a statement, the office said a resident found the ballots hidden under a rock near 99th and Glendale avenues and contacted the Glendale Police Department on Friday.

The Glendale Police Department shared a video of Brayan Ruiz, who said he found the ballots under concrete and rocks while at work at Rovey Farms. He kicked the rocks, saw they said something about elections, took a picture and sent it to his boss, who told him to bring them to the office and then they contacted Glendale police.

"I really have no information of who could have put them there, or how they got there. All I know is they were there and I took action and returned them to Glendale police," Ruiz said.

Investigators believe the mail-in ballots were stolen from individual mailboxes in a neighborhood just south of 107th and Northern avenues. The envelopes were still sealed.

Attorney General's Office agents and Glendale police officers hand-delivered the ballots back to the registered voters over the weekend.

The Attorney General's Office said the motive for stealing the ballots is unclear. An investigation is ongoing and no arrests have been made.

Anyone with information regarding the incident can submit tips to the Attorney General’s Election Integrity Unit online or email EIU@azag.gov.

Voters can check the status of their ballots on the Arizona Secretary of State’s website.

— Jessica Boehm

3 p.m.: 'A lemonade stand for democracy' in south Phoenix

Volunteers from United Farm Workers — some coming from other states in the West to focus on swing-state Arizona — have been hitting the pavement for months reaching voters in south Phoenix.

On Tuesday, the culmination of their efforts is a voter information booth at El Reposo Park, the site of the "Low Ridin' for Biden" event on Sunday, one of the organization’s last hurrahs to mobilize voters.

Organizers prepared a single table with treats and water in a cozy south Phoenix neighborhood between Seventh Street and Central Avenue.

“I would say, if anything, it’s a lemonade stand for democracy,” Elizabeth Strater, a UFW volunteer from California, said of the humble table. “Because this is a community that doesn’t feel represented, these are folks that may not know where they’re supposed to vote.”

So far, a little more than 35 people showed up to ask for information.

Communities like south Phoenix, which is home to some of the poorest neighborhoods in Phoenix and has the highest Black and Latino populations in the city, are often disproportionately affected by voter disenfranchisement. Often, the community is skeptical of candidates and information just doesn’t reach voters.

“The majority of people do want to be engaged, they just don’t have the tools to be engaged,” said Ernie Flores, a UFW volunteer from Yuma. “There’s no perfect representation, as Cesar Chavez said. There’s no perfect democracy, but there is perfect participation.”

He said it seems possible that Arizona will turn blue because of its Latino population, if not now, then in the future. He said Trump’s message to Latinos was that he was against them right off the bat, and that encouraged Latino voters to vote against him.

— Megan Taros

2:30 p.m.: Maricopa County approaches 100,000 voters

Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes said voter turnout in the county is in line with what officials expected, with about 99,000 voters casting ballots in person before 1:30 p.m.

That doesn't include other voters who dropped off their mail-in ballots at the polls.

Jordy and Alexis Berrelleza did just that.

The Phoenix siblings said they wanted to cast their first votes together. After their ballots arrived in the mail, Jordy, 19, walked his sister through the choices, explaining the options as simply as he could.

“In a non-biased way,” he said, grinning under his black mask, but the siblings voted mostly the same way anyway.

Before Election Day, they thought about mailing in their ballots, but all the noise surrounding the integrity of the election changed their minds.

“We felt like it was more secure to bring it in person,” Jordy said. So together they headed to the offices of the Phoenix Union High School District, where there was a steady stream of voters but no line.

In the end, Jordy said, they probably didn’t have any reason to worry.

“It would’ve been the same,” he said of mailing in their votes, “because we just dropped it in a box."

— Alden Woods and Mary Jo Pitzl

2 p.m.: Navajo voters cast ballots

Navajo voters streamed into the Steamboat Chapter House in Steamboat, Arizona, to cast their votes in Apache county.

Several election officials paced the grounds, instructing voters which line to stand in. There was a line to vote in Apache County for the national and state election, and a line for local Navajo Nation government elections.

The voting line for the county moved quickly and the local voting line had build up as more and more people turned out to vote.

Election officials made sure people in line maintained social distancing, kept face masks on and knew about hand-washing stations. They also checked temperatures before voters entered the building.

Andrew Simpson and his wife Bessie Yellowhair-Simpson, from Steamboat in northeastern Arizona, showed up at the polls to observe while they waited for family members to arrive from Phoenix. They both voted early by mail, but as community leaders — Andrew is a former council delegate and Bessi is the chapter treasurer — they stick around every Election Day.

Bessie, who is up for reelection, said she is use to seeing food stands lined up against the fence to feed voters before they head into the polls, but they couldn’t do that this year. The Navajo Nation Board of Elections sent out a memo before Election Day advising against food stands or political tents due to the pandemic.

“We just wanted to see people and our relatives,” he said, and he’s been able to recognize most of them through their masks. “There is still life out here.”

Andrew feels that both major political parties haven’t spent enough time on the Navajo Nation to really understand the way of life for Navajo people. But he has noticed that they’re paying more attention to Indigenous communities.

“Nobody ever paid attention to who we are," he said. He hopes in a few years it will only get better.

“They need to come here to understand us rather than try to change us into their way of life,” Andrew said. “Not only the Navajo Nation but all Native tribes. They need to understand our way of life.”

Volunteers say they've heard of issues at polling locations in Apache County.

12:45 p.m.: Lines still long in Scottsdale, issues in Tucson

11 a.m.: Complaint of man in Trump mask yelling at voters

10:30 a.m.: Smooth voting in Tucson, Cordes Lakes

In Cordes Lakes, a turn off Interstate 17 on the drive to northern Arizona, voters weren't blocked by long lines either.

The Cordes Lakes Community Center had a short line, people were mostly masked and many donned pro-Trump paraphernalia. A steady flow of cars ambled in and out of the gravel parking lot. Tranquil and quiet under expansive clouded skies, it was hard to believe people were there to cast their votes in the explosive 2020 presidential election.

Around 9:45 a.m., it began to rain, but people still stood dutifully outside.

Randy Rogers and Angie McFadin emerged from their white truck. Issues about the border and health care brought both to the polls near their home.

“I don’t like our two candidates, I’ll say that. I’m not a fan of either one of them,” Rogers said, walking toward the line stretching from the doorway of the one-story community center. “I was a Trump supporter last time because I liked what he had to say, and I’m definitely not a Democrat. Republicans want to take everything and Democrats want to give everything away.”

Unlike 2016, he said he isn’t voting for Trump in this election. For the first time in his life, he’s casting his vote for the third-party candidate on the ballot, Jo Jorgensen.

The change was largely due to the handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, Roger said. The infection had swept through his sister-in-law’s entire family.

“For me, I can’t vote for these two guys with a clear conscience,” he aid.

— Raphael Romero Ruiz, Emily Wilder

10:15 a.m.: Rain in Gilbert, lines in Scottsdale

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints had to close its doors and people made a dash for the dry interiors of their cars as rain came down in Gilbert.

Recent ASU graduate Cameryn Baum stood outside of the Higley Road polling station with her cello this morning. She hoped to inspire more people to head inside and vote.

Baum said she is participating in the nationwide Play for the Vote campaign, which is organizing musical performances throughout the country during Election Day to provide a positive incentive for people to head to the polls.

In Old Town Scottsdale, lines were long.

Earlier in the morning, more than 100 people waited in line to vote outside Mini Social, a multi-use events venue in Old Town Scottsdale.

The line of voters curved and winded around the store fronts of Fifth Avenue. Some people walking up to vote expressed sighs of frustration.

Scottsdale City Council candidate Betty Janik was making her way steadily through the line at 8 a.m., talking to voters about issues and answering their remaining questions about the candidates.

By 9 a.m. a volunteer had come outside to tell voters that there were several polling locations within four to six miles of Mini Social that had no wait times.

Minutes later, there were roughly 80 people in line with a wait time of 20 minutes.

— Kelly Donohue, Lorraine Longhi

9:45 a.m.: 'Hope that people are going to come together'

Voters were largely optimistic at the Southern Plaza voting center in south Phoenix.

Many emphasized the importance of the vote particularly in this tense and chaotic year, especially as Arizona stands on the precipice of historic change.

“If anything if Arizona stays Trump but then turns blue it’s going to be an interesting time in the country,” said voter Sentari Minor as he left the polling center.

The atmosphere was friendly as political opponents and compatriots appealed to voters outside the center. Mia Hill, another voter at the center, said that despite tension leading in to the election that the outcome must be a call to unity.

"It was important to me that I bought and contribute to a positive future," Hill said. "The fear of negative things happening, I think that’s all it is, is fear. I have hope that people are going to come together more than everything."

Jesus Olvera has children in school in south Phoenix. For him, the school board race was most important for his children’s future — but all the votes he cast were laying a foundation for them, he said.

He and other voters agreed the climate is ripe for change.

"I think there’s going to be a big change. I don’t know if it’s going to bring the results but it’s going to be a good time for us," Olvera said.

— Megan Taros

9:30 a.m.: Rep. Debbie Lesko alleges 'bias' at polling location

Rep. Debbie Lesko tweeted on Tuesday morning that a county poll worker in Sun City moved polling lines without measuring them and told Lesko she had to leave.

Lesko tweeted that she was at Radiant Church Sun City, near 107th Avenue and Boswell Bouelvard, when this happened.

"This is what's typical of some people that are biased," Lesko said in the video. "And it's wrong."

Megan Gilbertson, a spokesperson for the Maricopa County Elections Department, said workers at the site mistakenly thought it was a non-electioneering site. In Arizona, people aren't allowed to campaign or solicit votes within 75 feet of the polling place.

The location used to be one, but this year is not, Gilbertson said. The department addressed the mistake with the workers and Lesko, she said.

— Joshua Bowling

9:15 a.m.: First-time voters in the Ak-Chin Indian Community

Ak-Chin Indian Community had a quiet morning as people prepared for the day.

But at the tribe's community service center, slow but steady numbers of vehicles pull in as tribal members and community residents of the tribe exercise their right to vote.

Samantha Alejandro is married to an Ak-Chin tribal member. The mother of three arrived early to cast her vote. She said she is concerned with how fast the racial climate has changed. The first-time voter said she voted for Biden and Harris.

"I'm for peace," she said. "And we need to take steps to get there."

Another first-time voter had a different take.

"The way the president has handled the pandemic has been a disaster," said Jose Batopis III, 28.

Batopis, who's enrolled in the Yavapai-Apache Nation and also has Yaqui and Tohono O'odham heritage, lives in Ak-Chin and has lost an uncle, great-uncle and his grandfather to the coronavirus. He, too, voted for the Biden-Harris ticket. "They will take the country in a better direction," Batopis said.

Former tribal chairman and Elder Terry Enos has heard many candidate's promises for Indian Country.

"The president said he do a lot of things and did a 180 instead," Enos said. "Trump just doesn't get it."

On the other hand, Enos said that Biden walks softly but carries a big stick. He's not sure what will happen after the long count but still will urge his kids to come cast their vote.

Volunteers for Native Vote, a nationwide initiative that supports voting and deals with voting issues, were on hand for any problems. Anna Marie Smith and Annalise Parady came armed with brochures, information on the Native Vote Hotline for any problems and lots of water and snacks for the day.

— Debra Utacia Krol

9 a.m.: Mayoral races in Phoenix, Scottsdale and Gilbert

Phoenix's three-way race between incumbent Kate Gallego, Merissa Hamilton and Tim Seay is a primary election, meaning a candidate must get more than 50% of the vote to win outright on Tuesday. Otherwise, the race goes to a runoff between the top two vote-getters in March.

Both Scottsdale and Gilbert follow the more traditional election cycle in which the primary was held in August. Tuesday's runoff mayoral races feature Lisa Borowsky and David Ortega in Scottsdale and Matt Nielsen and Brigette Peterson in Gilbert.

Both Phoenix and Scottsdale have council races on the ballot, too.

The Scottsdale runoff features six candidates for three seats.

The Phoenix primary has contested races in the four council districts on the ballot. The most crowded race is in District 7, where five candidates vie to replace term-limited Michael Nowakowski representing parts of south, west and downtown Phoenix.

8:30 a.m.: Lines dwindle in Gilbert, West Valley

As lines at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert shortened after a busy morning, voters were able to get in and out of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints on Higley Road.

Veronica Parrillo, a first time nonpartisan volunteer, sat outside the polling place all morning to answer general questions that voters may have.

She said that the line had been moving pretty steadily.

"The longest I saw the line get was just over 20 minutes," Parillo said, adding that she expects more of a rush around lunchtime and later in the evening.

In Sun City West, lines had been virtually nonexistent since just after 6 a.m. Voters came by steadily but didn't have to wait in line.

Carolyn Gelazela volunteered to watch the polling location at the R.H. Johnson Recreation Center. Before she left her home Tuesday morning, her daughter reminded her to take her vitamins and told her not to be afraid of COVID-19.

The recreation center requires voters inside to wear a face covering. Most voters who came by Tuesday morning wore a face mask or other covering.

"I'm not a big believer in this whole pandemic thing. People are dying, but people die," Gelazela said, adding that she hopes for Republican victories as election results come in.

— Kelly Donohue, Adrienne Dunn

8 a.m.: McSally-Kelly Senate race captures eyes of the nation

The winner of the Arizona race to fill the seat initially won by the late Sen. John McCain could determine which party controls the U.S. Senate. Martha McSally, R-Ariz., and Mark Kelly, the Democratic challenger, fought hard in a high-profile, high-dollar race.

McSally, a former Air Force combat pilot, crisscrossed the state by plane on Sunday and Monday to visit 11 cities from Yuma to Kingman.

Recent polling suggests Kelly, a retired NASA astronaut, continues to lead in the race in the final days.

The winner likely will be on the ballot again in 2022; that's when McCain's term expires.

— Yvonne Wingett Sanchez

7:30 a.m.: Some voters see lines

Eric Kurland, a Democrat running for Arizona House of Representatives in Legislative District 23, visited the Islamic Center of the Northeast Valley in Scottsdale on Tuesday morning.

Kurland, a teacher, was clad in a T-shirt for his campaign and a face mask with symbols of education: sharpened pencils and bright red apples.

“I am just stunned by the amount of people that showed up this early for a vote that mostly everybody has already cast,” he said.

In Gilbert, Nicole Moon has been waiting in line to vote since 6:15 a.m. Tuesday. Moon, who works in communications, was still standing in line at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert shortly after 7 a.m.

She said she's concerned about unrest across the United States, no matter what the election results are.

"I think there's going to be a big political mess and probably some legal challenges," Moon said.

— Farah Eltohamy, Kelly Donohue

7 a.m.: Arizona is a battleground state this year. Here's why

Arizona is a magnet for transplants from across the country and has a large, Democratic-leaning Hispanic population that voted in more sizable numbers in 2018.

Along with a large independent electorate that swung mostly to Democrats two years ago, these factors helped push the state — once the base of GOP presidential nominees Barry Goldwater and John McCain — to battleground status.

Growing signs indicate these demographic trends could make it harder for President Donald Trump to hold on to a state he carried by 3.5% points in 2016. Recent polls show Biden in the lead.

— Ronald J. Hansen

6:30 a.m.: Voters waited for polling places to open

A steady stream of voters lined up early at the Southeast Regional Library in Gilbert.

Dozens were already waiting outside before the polling place opened at 6 a.m. The line grew and stretched into the parking lot within 30 minutes .

Voters were mostly masked and socially distanced as they waited to go inside and cast their votes.

Across the Valley in Sun City West, a short but steady stream of voters made their way into the active adult community's R.H. Johnson Recreation Center.

— Kelly Donohue, Adrienne Dunn

6 a.m.: Arizona polls open for historic 2020 election

Polling places are in new locations this election, and Maricopa County voters can cast a ballot at any polling place, now called vote centers, rather than at an assigned polling place. COVID-19 precautions are in place. Masks are available to voters who did not bring them.

Vote centers, ballot drop boxes and drive-thru drop boxes will be open from 6 a.m. until polls close at 7 p.m. Tuesday.

Locations for drop boxes and vote centers can be found at locations.maricopa.vote or by calling 602-506-1511.

For voters who:

Got a ballot in the mail but didn't send it back yet: Drop it off at any drop box or vote center.

Got a ballot in the mail but misplaced it: Get a new one at any vote center.

Want to vote in person: Go to any vote center. See here for what you should bring.

Overall, voting has gone smoothly since the county began opening vote centers and mailing out ballots on Oct. 7. By about noon Monday, the county had processed ballots for about 64.4% of the county's registered voters. That's about 1.68 million ballots out of 2.61 million registered voters.

By Sunday, early voting in the county had already surpassed total voting in 2016.

— Jen Fifield

search_result.title: Colts Jim Irsay, Chris Ballard, Jeff Saturday address media Monday
search_result.text:
The Indianapolis Colts pulled off two franchise-altering moves on Monday morning: First, they fired head coach Frank Reich in the midst of his fifth season with the team. Later, they named Jeff Saturday, a Colts legend with no NFL or college coaching experience, as his interim replacement.

Colts owner Jim Irsay, general manager Chris Ballard and Saturday addressed the media on Monday night.

Here's what they said:

Jim Irsay:

"We certainly are excited about going forward with our future. First and foremost, a big thank you to Frank Reich. He's someone that's very close tot he organization, to my family, to myself, to Chris, to Jeff. It's a very difficult and tough day. I told Frank I was hoping Chris and him and I were going to grab that Lombardi trophy someday. This league is tough and things change. He's a pro. he understands this league and this business. It was a difficult decision to make ... There's no rulebook that tells you, 'Now you should make a change, now you shouldn't.' It's intuitive.

Follow every game: Live NFL Scores

"I've been fortunate and blessed on the path of bringing in coaches. Chris and I met Sunday night face to face in a difficult conversation ... Expectations are high here. We've earned (winning). What we've accomplished speaks for itself. I told Frank that expectations are high. He's a winning head coach. If anyone wants to diminish what Coach did, you'd be wrong. The numbers don't lie. You are what your record is. But it was time."

Irsay on Jeff Saturday: Yes, he is fully experienced enough. He's capable. He's extremely smart and competitive ... You want to bet against this guy? Put your money down people. I know what he's about.

Irsay on Saturday's experience: Yes, there's a maturation curve. No, the game is not different. We don't build rockets to go to Mars. It's a very simple job we do here. We cultivate winning cultures. We don't expect anything more than we expect from ourselves. I'm not going to ask someone to do something I haven't done. I know who we are. I know where we're going.

I know people can look out and see it and ask (the experience) question. I understand. I don't know how to make sausage, but I do know how to build a football team. He's fully capable of doing this. It wasn't offered to anyone else. I don;'t know what Chris and I would have done if he wasn't available and willing.

Irsay on Saturday's future: Yes, it's an interim coaching job. it lines up with the Rooney Rule. After the season, there will be a full process for interviewing. This is for eight games, hopefully more. All I'm thinking about is the Raiders ... There's no talk of permanence at this point.

Irsay on other candidates: I wanted a winning coach, a winning playoff coach that was proven. Now, I'm glad he doesn't have NFL experience and that he hasn't learned the fear that's in this league. There was no other candidate. We were fortunate he was available. He has tons of experience.

Irsay on why it was time to make a change: You never like to make a change, much less during the season. It's not ideal. Chris and I saw things collapse. I saw things go from bad to worse. I thought it was time to make a change.

Irsay on Ballard: Chris was highly sought after. The guy's a winner and he's been immensely successful. In this league, it's tough. Sometimes you don't understand how fortunate you are when you're around success. He fits right into that culture.

Irsay said "of course" Ballard will be back next season.

We're fortunate to have him. These things don't always work out in our favor. We know things have drifted. Sometimes that happens in this game. The math doesn't always work in this league. From my perspective, we're fortunate to have Chris.

You try to get the right mixture going at the right time. We're fortunate to have this guy. We know it's about winning. There's a lot to consider before we'd make a change (at general manager)

Irsay on decision to move on from Reich: Chris knows you keep names in your pocket, but you're always ready for anything to happen within your own coaching staff, within the league, in college. You have to. Believe me, it was a debate society. We're all trying to strive for the right thing. I stay open-minded.

Irsay on choosing Saturday over other coaches with experience: He's a better fit (than assistants with previous experience). He's the best man for the job, and there's no question about it in my mind. I've been around it a long time. He's extremely tough and he's a leader. You have to be a great thinker, work with people, be open-minded, create a culture where people trust you. You have to have experience, draw on experience in your life. You know it when you see it. Let's be clear, this thing was driven by what Chris and I see in his excellence and readiness and who he is.

OPINION:Colts hiring Jeff Saturday as interim head coach is slap in the face of Black coaches

OPINION:If Indianapolis Colts coach Frank Reich had to go, and he did, so does GM Chris Ballard

4th & MONDAY:Our NFL newsletter always brings the blitz

Jeff Saturday:

Saturday has met with the offensive staff. "There are fantastic coaches on this staff and men who have done this a long time. I have no fear I will pick the right guy (for offensive coordinator) and we will ride with it.

Saturday on reaction when he was offered the job: Shock would be an understatement. We had the conversation and it escalated quickly. He asked me and my wife. He told me he was going to meet with Chris about it. As the day progressed, we finally came to a conclusion. It was a 12-hour whirlwind. It was a late call.

I feel fully capable, excited about the opportunity. If it goes well, hopefully it will go extremely well ... The job is win. This is an audition for this job and 31 other jobs.

I'd be shocked as well. I'll be frank, I asked Mr. Irsay, 'Tell me why I'm a candidate you'd consider in any role to do this.' I felt very prepared. When Peyton retired from Denver, I spent some time with John Lynch ... Every year, I've done a sheet of the best OCs, the best DCs, who you want in that building.

Irsay said Saturday's "leadership" set him apart. "I've been with Hall of Famers. I've seen great leadership at its pinnacle. I'm a leader of men. I don't shy away from it and I'm excited about it."

Saturday said Sam Ehlinger will be QB on Sunday.

I am who I am. I don't change. I'm probably more spirited than most. I'll hold people accountable. I'm going to be your toughest critic and your biggest cheerleader.

Saturday said he'll have to win over the locker room. "You've to earn your place here. We're all on a trial basis. Only one guy up here is secure, and he's in the middle. I hope they understand the expectation I have for them is no different than the expectations I have for myself. I've spent my life in a locker room. If they see I'm authentic, we'll do just fine."

Chris Ballard:

After the game, Irsay and I visited. It was spirited. Last night, we talked about jeff. We've tried to hire Jeff a couple times in 2019 as the offensive line coach and again this year. The timing didn't work out ... He's got real leadership in him. Real special in that regard. For this eight game stretch, we thought it was going to be a good fit for us.

We’ve got eight games left. I’m not ready to throw in the towel. I talked to the team and the coaches. Frank, Jim and I met about the Ryan decision. We had a long talk late last night. I talked to Frank this morning.

We both know we haven’t been perfect in any stretch. It was a hard morning.

Defensively, we’re playing pretty good football. Offensively, we’ve got to make some hay. We’re underperforming on the offensive line right now.

You can’t win games turning the football over in this league.

search_result.title: Colts mailbag: Could Sean Payton be the next head coach? What is ...
search_result.text:
The past week has been quite a year on the Colts beat.

On Monday morning, I woke up at 5:30 a.m. in a hotel in Boston and headed for the airport. I got back home in Indianapolis at 11:30 that morning, sat down to do a little work and got the news that Frank Reich had been fired. Then came the bombshell that Jeff Saturday would replace him.

Then came a wild press conference that night.

I finally got to bed at 3 a.m. I've had some crazy days in this field, from seeing the Big Ten Tournament canceled to a Lions practice in a blizzard to a Lions coach's press conference discussing an allegation for sexual assault, but Monday had to be the strangest from start to finish.

It's never a dull day covering these 2022 Colts. It also means you have questions, and I tried my best to deliver some answers.

Follow every game: Live NFL Scores

(If you'd like to submit a mailbag question, email the link at the bottom or follow me on Twitter @NateAtkins_, where I put out the call.)

Question: "Jeff Saturday was a head-scratching decision, to say the least. How will that affect the Colts head coach search in the offseason? Would Sean Payton have any interest in coaching the Colts after this? He have said he doesn't want to go to a dysfunctional place and the Colts seems to be one." -- @_Not_DBCooper via Twitter

Answer: The Colts are making so many changes right now that it can be hard to keep track of. In less than three weeks, they have benched an MVP quarterback for a sixth-round pick, they've fired an offensive coordinator, they've fired a head coach and offensive play caller and they've hired an interim coach from an analyst job at ESPN.

They are doing it to best manage and react to a season that has fallen so far below anyone's expectations, but they have to be careful about the image this projects around the league. The nation tuned in for Monday's press conference with popcorn. My phone was blowing up with people asking what on earth had infected this franchise. It's undercutting all the stability and infrastructure that had made it a prized destination for a Hall-of-Fame-caliber quarterback like Matt Ryan just eight months ago. Jim Irsay now comes off as an owner calling the shots, particularly with his quarterbacks, to the point of hiring a former player he likes in order to smooth it over. Whether that's fair or not, it's the perception they have to fight. It's an image of meddling that has made franchises like the Browns, Raiders, Jets, Dolphins and Washington what they have been over the past few decades.

FOR SUBSCRIBERS: Jeff Saturday is an unconventional hire. Can he become a rare success with Colts?

That doesn't bode well for negotiations with future head coaches or general managers who have other options. Sean Payton will certainly be one of those, and he comes from a place in New Orleans where he had total roster control, something that's not on the table with the Colts right now. Payton is a longshot for other reasons, too: He will prioritize having a quarterback in place, and he'll also cost significant draft compensation to the Saints. The Colts need their draft picks to find a quarterback and a left tackle to attract him in the first place.

Also, consider the words he told The Athletic recently:

"I think there are a lot of dysfunctional teams in our league. There are some places where talent can die," Payton said. "I just want to avoid those places."

Question: "Why is Jimmy from the Colts the way that he is? But seriously, what the hell was that press conference? Irsay was so smug and arrogant while Ballard looked like he’d rather be anywhere but there. Embarrassed as a fan/season ticket holder is an understatement." -- @MitchMullis via Twitter

Answer: That was a trip. So much surprised me about the Colts' approach that night -- the lack of an opening statement for Saturday or Chris Ballard, Irsay's opening defense of the coach he just fired, the deflection of criticism, the bathing in the success of the early 2000s and the refusal to acknowledge what's changed.

Perhaps the weirdest moment to me was one I haven't seen get a lot of play elsewhere: when Irsay made up a reference from a deceased Al Davis to promote his new coach.

"If Al was here and you’d say, ‘Hey Al, why do you think Jeff (Saturday) is going to be successful?’ He’d say three words: ‘He’s not scared,’” Irsay said.

The defensiveness of Irsay and Ballard caught me by surprise. Ballard thrives on confidence, but it doesn't usually rear its head after failure. Irsay has always been engaging and relatable to the fans' frustration, but the night became a victory lap for his tenure, when it was the mistakes that led to the press conference for a fired coach. It all took the focus off of Saturday, a franchise legend who showed a relatable and passionate personality but was overshadowed by the leaders above him. That's becoming a theme of the 2022 Colts.

This was Ballard and Irsay in a place we haven't seen them before. Both men have proven to me and others to be much better than they showed that night. You hope they can rebound to what they used to be instead of just talking about what they used to be.

Question: "What changes will be made to improve line play and the offense in general?" -- @chuckinfoosier via Twitter

Answer: Saturday is going to need some time to assess the situation before too many changes take place.

He gave some interesting insight in his first solo press conference Wednesday when he shared that Irsay called him in the middle of Sunday's 26-3 loss to the Patriots to ask what was so wrong with an offensive line that would go on to give up nine sacks, their most since 2017.

"I was not watching that game. I was preparing to go to work. So, I was watching all the other games. I actually watched the Colts at 7 – my schedule for working for ESPN," Saturday said. "... This was 100% about what happened to our o-line and that was the role that I had been doing with Strauss (Chris Strausser) and Frank (Reich)."

Everything has been a whirlwind for Saturday since that call. He discussed the opportunity with his wife, accepted the job, flew from Georgia to Indianapolis, met his coaching staff for the first time, interviewed offensive coaches to find a play-caller, met with the team, met with trainers to learn about the health situation of the 53 men on the roster and then started to formulate a practice plan.

"I’m drinking from a fire hydrant a little bit," Saturday said.

What we do know is that Sam Ehlinger will start at quarterback, Bernhard Raimann will start at left tackle and assistant quarterbacks coach Parks Frazier will call the plays. Ehlinger has started the past two games and Raimann started last week. Frazier has never called plays at any level before, but he's as on top of the details of Reich's playbook and philosophy as anyone and has worked with Ehlinger behind the scenes. His knowledge of what Ehlinger can and can't do should be a bonus, but he has catching up to do with the rest of the personnel.

Like any coaching staff, they'll adapt some as they gain practice time and see the picture evolve on the field. They'll also work with what they have. The real fixes the Colts need on offense aren't walking through that door right now. The players and coaches are all so young and inexperienced everywhere but the offensive line, and that's been the unit that has held everything back.

Question: "If they miss playoffs, you think Chris Ballard is done in offseason so new GM can pick his own coach?" -- @MIKE_R_MARSHALL via Twitter

Answer: It's going to be very unlikely that the Colts make the playoffs with the changes they've introduced to a 3-5-1 team. Projecting beyond that gets very difficult.

Irsay was asked on Monday whether Ballard will be back, an admittedly awkward but unavoidable moment with Ballard sitting directly to his left.

"There’s no question about that," Irsay said. "Honestly, it’s not really even in the consciousness of my mind about that sort of thing."

It's a vote of confidence, technically. But keep in mind Irsay's track record with these promises. He said last spring that Ryan would be the starting quarterback for at least two seasons and hopefully a third, and that lasted seven games. He recently told ESPN and NFL Network that Reich's job was safe, and that lasted eight days.

I brought those two moments to his attention Monday night and asked him why fans should believe the promises he's now making about his head coach and general manager.

“I’ve never hired a losing head coach," Irsay said. "We’re the fourth-winningest team in the league. It’s not about belief, it’s about fact. What we’ve done. We’re better than most all. It’s that simple. Our record proves it over a period of time. So, you don’t have to believe much when it’s there in black and white."

So, the track record suggests the words aren't what matters. Irsay says he makes these decisions based on intuition, so we'll see how he feels about the final eight games and what Saturday reports back to him about the state of his franchise.

Question: "Is this the year the Colts finally go and draft a QB in the first round regardless of whatever draft position they end up in?" -- @AarBagg via Twitter

Answer: It certainly should be, but you really can't assume anything with this franchise at the moment. If they have a plan in place, they're doing a great job of hiding it, and they also seem ripe to blow it up at any moment. Nobody knows who will be the general manager of this team come next spring, so projecting what will happen is impossible.

But we know Irsay wants to build around a young quarterback, something he pressed upon our columnist, Gregg Doyel, just a week ago.

They might not have much of a choice either.

The tenures with Matt Ryan and Nick Foles have gone so publicly bad that it's going to be a monstrous challenge to convince another veteran quarterback to want to make Indianapolis the destination if he has any options at all. Ryan and Foles both did. The Colts had to talk Ryan into requesting a trade from Atlanta to Indianapolis by selling him on their offensive line and running game and promising at least two years as the starter, claims that Irsay made public with his comments and by guaranteeing the second year of Ryan's deal, and they pulled the rug out after seven games. Foles was content with retiring after playing for five teams in 11 seasons. Both men didn't want to move young families across the country unless it was for more than a year, and the Colts promised them both that, and then neither had a chance at the roles they were given by midseason, and the coach who sold them on it was fired.

That's one of the issues the Colts are having with their chaotic management of this season. The franchise has gone from a golden destination for quarterbacks to a death trap in the eyes of the public. Add in the poor offensive line play and the lack of defined leadership at the general manager, head coach and offensive coordinator level, and it's not the stable place veteran quarterbacks seek out. It's also not a stable place for a rookie either, but draft picks don't get the same choice.

What the Colts do from now until next year's draft will determine plenty about whether the next quarterback can sink or swim.

Contact Colts insider Nate Atkins at natkins@indystar.com. Follow him on Twitter @NateAtkins_.

search_result.title: COVID bivalent booster dose: Moderna or Pfizer? When should I get ...
search_result.text:
Health experts are urging Americans to get their bivalent booster as soon as possible.

CDC data shows only about 1.5% of eligible Americans have gotten their shot since the rollout.

With fall in full swing, experts recommend getting a flu shot and COVID booster at the same time.

Health officials are still urging Americans to get a bivalent booster nearly a month after the Food and Drug Administration authorized the COVID-19 shots targeting the omicron variant.

A look at cases and deaths: 13 states had more cases in the latest week than in the week before, and 20 states had more deaths, according to a USA TODAY analysis of Johns Hopkins University data.

A look at booster numbers: About 4.4 million people have received a bivalent COVID-19 booster since the start of the month, representing only 1.5% eligible Americans, according to data released Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

Where do boosters for kids stand? Both Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna have submitted requests to the FDA to get their shots authorized for emergency use in younger children, but it's unclear when they'll become available.

What does bivalent mean?

Answer: Bivalent boosters combine the original COVID-19 vaccine with a reformulation that targets the BA.4 and BA.5 versions of the omicron variant.

Both the original COVID-19 vaccines and the updated bivalent boosters use messenger RNA technology.

In the original vaccines, mRNA instructs body’s cells to produce spike proteins similar to those on the surface of the original coronavirus. The immune system recognizes those vaccine-created spike proteins as invaders and creates antibodies to block future attacks of the real virus.

The bivalent booster combines the original vaccine and a reformulation targeting a mutated spike protein found on the omicron BA.4 and BA.5 variants, so the immune system can create antibodies that combat both the original coronavirus and the omicron variants.

The BA.5 strain is the predominant variant circulating the country, making up more than 85% of new COVID-19 cases in the U.S., according to the CDC.

When should I get a bivalent COVID booster?

Answer: Now.

White House COVID-19 coordinator Dr. Ashish Jha said everyone should get their bivalent booster shot by Oct. 31. But with fall in full swing, health experts are urging Americans not to wait, as they expect coronavirus cases to rise in the coming months.

“I am recommending anyone that asks me to get it as soon as they can,” said Libby Richards, associate professor of nursing at Purdue University’s College of Health and Human Sciences. “It takes two weeks for the body to start to develop antibodies, meaning it takes two weeks for you to gain protections against the new COVID variant.”

Health experts say immunity from the bivalent booster should carry through the holiday season, which will not only protect the person getting vaccinated, but also vulnerable loved ones during family gatherings.

How to find a booster shot near me

Answer: Vaccines.gov.

Major pharmacy retailers like CVS and Walgreens say they're offering both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech bivalent vaccines, depending on the location. Both companies say they welcome walk-ins, but encourage patients to schedule an appointment online.

The Biden administration also urges Americans to take advantage of its vaccine locator website, vaccines.gov. By entering your ZIP code, you can find a list of sites where their preferred vaccine is available.

I just recovered from COVID. Should I wait to get boosted?

Answer: People who have recently recovered from COVID-19 should still get boosted, experts say, as data suggests immunity from prior infection may not be as protective as vaccine-induced immunity.

A 2021 study from the CDC found people were over five times more likely to get COVID-19 three to six months after a prior infection if they were unvaccinated, compared with those who were fully vaccinated and were never infected.

Other studies have also shown vaccination after a COVID-19 infection may offer broader protection, leading to a hybrid or "super immunity," experts say.

“You probably have some protection for some amount of time, in the order of weeks to months,” said Dr. David Cennimo, an infectious disease expert at Rutgers New Jersey Medical School. “But there’s really good immunology data saying that after an infection, taking a vaccine really locks in that high level of antibody immunity.”

Should I get Moderna or Pfizer? Can I mix and match?

Answer: Get whatever bivalent booster shot is available, experts say.

Pfizer and Moderna's bivalent booster both use mRNA technology combining the original COVID-19 vaccine along with the reformulation targeting the BA.4 and BA.5 versions of the omicron variant.

Pfizer-BioNTech: The companies' bivalent booster is authorized by the Food and Drug Administration at 30 micrograms to anyone 12 years old and older at least two months after any previous COVID-19 shots

The companies' bivalent booster is authorized by the Food and Drug Administration at 30 micrograms to anyone 12 years old and older at least two months after any previous COVID-19 shots Moderna: The FDA authorized Moderna's bivalent booster at 50 micrograms for adults 18 and older.

CDC guidance says FDA-authorized boosters can be mixed and matched after completing a primary series. Those who have gotten Pfizer boosters in the past can get Moderna’s bivalent booster, and vice versa.

Is the bivalent booster shot safe? What are the side effects?

Answer: Clinical trials in people have yet to be completed, but health experts say there are no safety concerns with the bivalent booster. The FDA said study participants who received the bivalent vaccine reported some side effects like pain, redness and swelling at the injection site, fatigue, headache, muscle and joint pain.

Although there's limited data, health experts agree the new boosters are safe and will provide broader protection against omicron variants.

FDA commissioner Dr. Robert Califf said that if the agency waited until studies were completed in another month or two, "the (COVID) wave will have passed us by and the damage will have been done. ... We have to be a step ahead, or at least we have to try to be."

Boosters for kids:Pfizer-BioNTech asks FDA to authorize new omicron-targeting COVID booster for children 5 to 11

Can I get the flu shot and the bivalent booster at the same time?

Answer: Yes!

As the country enters flu season, health officials are encouraging Americans to get their flu shot and COVID-19 booster in the same visit.

"I really believe this is why God gave us two arms," Jha said during a White House briefing. "One for the flu shot and the other for the COVID shot."
